DOC.brief_summary: This is a pilot study to investigate the effect of TL01 narrow band UVB therapy on the resident dermal dendritic cells characterized by expression of CD1c and CD141. These cells were reported to have a role in induction of tolerogenic regulatory T cells and production of IL-10. The investigators proposed to investigate the effect of NB-UVB on these subsets of cells after two weeks of treatment to provide better understanding of the mechanism of action of light treatment.
DOC.brief_title: Anti-psoriatic Effect of TL01 Light Therapy
DOC.detailed_description: Six patients with plaque psoriasis were recruited from the phototherapy unit. These patients were referred by their dermatologist to receive narrow-band UVB (TL01) light treatment. Two 6 mm lesional skin punch biopsies were taken at baseline and 2 weeks after commencing the light treatment to study the effect of light on innate immune cells involved in psoriasis pathogenesis.
DOC.criteria: Male and female psoriasis patients in whom the decision to treat with NBUVB therapy, as part of their routine clinical care, has been taken by their dermatologist in the age range of 1870 years. patients currently on antipsoriatic treatment. Patients with immunosuppressive diseases Patients on immunosuppressive therapies Pregnant or lactating female patients Patients unable to provide a written consentProcedure
DOC.keyword: psoriasis patients referred to receive TL01 NB-UVB therapy
